feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 3:58AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Elevated Surf Expected Wednesday Night Through Friday... Elevated surf is expected along the western Arctic coast from near Point Hope to Wainwright. North to northwesterly winds will increase on Wednesday to 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph. Strong winds will cause elevated surf for coastal areas. Winds will gradually decrease Friday. Wave action may cause minor
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Arctic Coast; Western Arctic Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 3:58AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Blowing Snow This Afternoon and Tonight... Gusty east winds of 20 to 30 mph this morning will shift to the west this afternoon and increase to 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph. The combination of gusty winds and periods of snow will lead to areas of blowing snow through tonight. Visibility may be reduced to less than a mile at times this evening and tonight.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 3:57AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Elevated Surf Expected Wednesday Through Friday... Elevated surf is expected along the Chukchi Sea coast, including Kotzebue Sound and north-facing coasts of the Seward Peninsula. North to northwesterly winds will increase on Wednesday to 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 50 mph. Strong winds will cause elevated surf for coastal areas of the Chukchi Sea. Winds will gradually
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baldwin Peninsula; Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Noatak Valley; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 3:16PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: Low pressure will move into the Gulf of Alaska Tuesday morning, bringing widespread heavy rain along with strong winds through Thursday. Confidence is high on strong gusts greater than 40 mph along with widespread rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches across the region. Strong winds from this storm combined with saturated soils will also bring concerns for tree falls, mainly along river
entry.cap:areaDesc: Admiralty Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau; City and Borough of Sitka; City and Borough of Wrangell; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island

entry.title: Heat Advisory issued October 17 at 4:07AM AST until October 17 at 5:00PM AST by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM THIS MORNING TO 5 PM AST THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Heat indices of 108 to 111 degrees Fahrenheit. * WHERE...Urban and coastal areas from Mayaguez to Arecibo, and from San Juan and vicinity to Fajardo, Vieques, and USVI. * WHEN...From 10 AM through 5 PM AST this afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: St Croix; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 7:04AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...PATCHY DENSE FOG ACROSS SOUTHERN WISCONSIN UNTIL 9 AM... Patchy dense fog is occurring across southern Wisconsin this morning. Motorists should be prepared for rapidly changing visibility down to less than a quarter mile at times. The fog is primarily in river valleys and low lying areas such as marshes. Fog is expected to dissipate between 8 and 9 AM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia; Dane; Dodge; Fond Du Lac; Green; Green Lake; Iowa; Jefferson; Lafayette; Marquette; Rock; Sauk; Washington; Waukesha

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 6:15AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...LOCALLY DENSE FOG AFFECTING PORTIONS OF NORTHWESTERN WISCONSIN... Areas of locally dense fog will affect areas across northwestern Wisconsin early this morning. Visibilities of less than a mile have already been observed, which should persist through the overnight hours. Visibilities are expected to improve

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 5:44AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...WATCH OUT FOR PATCHY DENSE FOG THIS MORNING... Patchy dense fog was reported across parts of central and east central Wisconsin early this morning. Watch out for rapidly changing visibilities if driving this morning. The fog is most likely near lakes and river valleys. It should dissipate shortly after 8am.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 3:26AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Areas of Dense Fog Through This Morning... Pockets of dense fog have developed early this morning across western Wisconsin. Visibilities may drop to a half mile or less at times. If traveling, use caution and be prepared for sudden changes in visibility. Conditions will improve by mid morning.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:19AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Pockets Of Dense Fog Early This Morning... Areas of fog have developed early this morning, becoming dense in some river valleys and other low lying areas. If traveling through the early morning hours, be prepared for sudden reductions in visibilities...especially near water ways. The fog should start to lift and dissipate by mid morning.
